rev.comment: /* Dialects */ maltese is not an Arabic dialect, it's partially derived from it
/* Phonology */ marking ipa as such; ents -> chars; consistent with Arabic alphabet; misc cleanup, but could still use some more.
Rv. Even ''if'' Western Sahara/SADR is not a country, Gaza Strip and West Bank aren't either. Should we delete them, too?
rev edits by Koavf to last edition by Russbot - SADR/WS is not a country to be enlisted there
countries which use the language are already listed
There are too many notable dialects to just list two

/* External links */ removed external link to non existing page
removed external link to full add page
removed external link to ad displayed page (misleading link tile).
rm Malta - the Maltese consider their language to be non-Arabic, unlike the others listed, and their choice should be respected. Also, not majority in Israel.
Restore [[Malta]] - Maltese is a *spoken form* of Arabic. No one in the Arab world actually speaks pure Standard Arabic anyway.
added link to Common phrases in various languages

rv; the countries mentioned are not really the best or most representative examples of where Arabic is spoken by a minority

that box lists countries with Arabic-speaking majorities; official language is further down
remnant of no-italics hack no longer needed
Quite a few English words are ultimately derived from Arabic, often through other European languages
/* Phonology */ this is debatable, but `ayn should be the rverse in IPA
"Palestine" is not a country. Replaced by proper geographical and political terms.

there is no contradiction in Maltese being synchronically a distinct language and diachronically a dialect of Arabic; the same question has been raised for other "dialects" of Arabic
If Maltese is a distinct language, it shouldn't be listed as a dialect of Arabic. The earlier reference to Maltese is also of limited relevance here.

rm reference to numerals altogether. not the subject of this article.
